lead_paragraph: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorities, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
abstract: New York Times investigation finds that more than dozen prominent Washington research groups have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments in recent years while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect donors' priorities; money is increasingly transforming once-staid think-tank world into muscular arm of foreign governments' lobbying in Washington.

snippet: Mohammad Ali, 21, was captured by his male in-laws and dragged to a police station, where he was accused of kidnapping his wife, Zakia, 18, whom he had married for love.

abstract: Plight of Afghan couple Mohammad Ali and his pregnant wife Zakia has brought attention to culture's treatment of those accused of social crimes; having married against wishes of his wife's family, Ali is charged with kidnapping, which carries death penalty in Afghanistan; Zakia's family members have publicly declared their attention to kill her for dishonoring them by marrying outside her ethnic group; she has taken refuge in a women's shelter.

lead_paragraph: Renewed Israel-Hamas fighting after the collapse of truce talks in Cairo highlights the steep obstacles to ending the Gaza war. Israel's leadership is under domestic pressure not to hand achievements to Hamas after the Islamic militant group fired thousands of rockets at Israel in the past six weeks. Hamas feels it can't afford to settle for vague Israeli promises about an easing of the blockade of the strip after a war that killed more than 2,000 Gazans and left 100,000 homeless. With chances for diplomacy fading, there's a risk of protracted fighting. Here's a look at what each side wants.

snippet: Libya is being torn apart by an escalating war among its patchwork of rival cities and tribes, and an assault that destroyed its main airport last month has exacerbated the nation’s divisions.
lead_paragraph: Libya is being torn apart by an escalating war among its patchwork of rival cities and tribes, and an assault that destroyed its main airport last month has exacerbated the nation’s divisions.
abstract: Ultraconservative Islamist Salah Badi's assault on Libya's main international airport in July has drawn country's fractious militias and tribes into single national conflagration that threatens to become prolonged civil war; while both Badi's backers and his opponents publicly profess similar conservative but democratic vision, it is clear that Libya is being torn apart by escalating war among its patchwork of rival cities and tribes.

headline.main: Strife in Libya Could Presage Long Civil War
headline.print_headline: Strife in Libya Could Presage Long Civil War

byline.contributor: Suliman Ali Zway and Osama Alfitory contributed reporting.

snippet: Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir underwent successful minor surgery on one of his knees on Sunday and will handle his duties from a Khartoum hospital for two to three days as he recovers, a presidential spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir underwent successful minor surgery on one of his knees on Sunday and will handle his duties from a Khartoum hospital for two to three days as he recovers, a presidential spokesman said.

headline.main: Sudan's President Bashir Undergoes Knee Operation

snippet: The big German bank said that investigations begun last year by regulators in Germany, Britain, the United States and elsewhere could have a material financial effect.
abstract: The big German bank said that investigations begun last year by regulators in Germany, Britain, the United States and elsewhere could have a material financial effect.

headline.main: Deutsche Bank Warns Investors on Currency Investigation
headline.print_headline: Potential Risk

snippet: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was the first high-level official to publicly face lawmakers about a prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was the first high-level official to publicly face lawmakers about a prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.
abstract: Defiant Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel defends prisoner exchange that freed Sgt Bowe Bergdahl after years of captivity with the Taliban, telling skeptical lawmakers that decision had been kept secret from Congress because leaks could have scuttled deal or increased risks to soldier before the swap; is first high-level official to publicly face Congress about prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.

headline.main: Hagel Defends Bergdahl Trade as a Part of Waging War
